text: There's nothing inherently wrong with defensive programming, especially if you enjoy developing a codebase littered with foot guns.

Theory: a preference for defensive programming over fail-fast correlates with big tech. Maybe because the price of whole system failure is higher at big tech. Maybe because there's a chance you might escape being assigned the bug down the line.
Don't run CI on your code if test failures won't block merge. It's a waste of compute. Similarly, CI tests should be stable modulo solar flares. Anything less stable should be a low severity alert.

Small teams must be efficient with time. Code velocity is essential. Make choices that maximize reuse of work. Use a monorepo. Write CI/CD once. Enforce code quality strictly. Colocate code to promote collaboration, discoverability, and component reuse.
Monorepo does not imply monolith. You can keep your code in one place while still having clear module boundaries and isolated components and services.

Pull request reviews are a courtesy and a favor, not owed. You're requesting someone's valuable time to help you avoid mistakes, since ultimately you're responsible for any mess you merge. Ask nicely.
Strive for all 'adds' in pull requests. If you have very few lines deleted/modified, it's a good sign your codebase is modular and maintainable.
Never use GitHub's 'Request Changes' feature. It encourages a confrontational style of code review. Remember that #pr-reviews-are-a-courtesy.
Strive to review small PRs quickly. This incentivizes small diffs, provides immediate reward signals for hard work, and builds trust and goodwill within a team.

Don't be afraid to delete unused code. Code is cheap and git is good. If something isn't directly contributing to your mission and won't in the immediate future, delete it. It can always be resurrected if needed.
Code review is purely static analysis. It's the pull request author's responsibility to test runtime behavior of their code, not reviewers'.
Set up structured logging early. You get 90% of the value of all observability tooling just be having quality logging from the start.

If you always choose execution speed over quality, good luck maintaining that speed. Consider second and third order effects. Remember that this tradeoff is a balancing act and always situationally dependent.
The pull request author should merge their own PRs. The author knows best whether the code is ready and safe to merge.

It seems that people underestimate the cost of pinning dependencies. It's a pretty serious form of tech debt that feels small in the moment, but can become a huge headache after adding just a few constraints.
Your production codebase should only have code that is shipped to production and tests. One off benchmarks, notebooks, and scripts should live elsewhere.

All code merged to the production codebase should be tested, either by a unit test or an end to end test. You don't need 100% test coverage, but this is a good heuristic to ensure everything in your production repo is stable.

Code quality checks should run on every single line of application code merged to the production repo. This repo is the boundary between one off scripts and the code that becomes your product. Structure it accordingly into packages with carefully configured CI.

If you find yourself needing to write a patch in your tests, this should ring a bell in your head that your code could be structured better. Consider how to make your application code more "pure", more functional, perhaps using dependency injection.

In all work you do, make a clear distinction between adding functionality and refactoring. It's up to you whether to refactor before or after implementing new functionality, but strive to avoid mixing the two.
